def: Origin of Mathematics, Pure Mathematics (Study of math for it's own sake: Number systems, structures, spaces, changes), Applied Mathematics (when you develop math to solve real world problems: Physics, Chemistry, Biomathematics, engineering, numberical analysis, game theory, economics, probability, statistics, control theory, decision theory, information theory, computer science, optimization, cryptography), Foundations (this area tries to work out the properties of mathematics itself: fundamental rules, logic, set theory, category theory, theory of computation, complexity

Number systems (natural numbers, integers, rational numbers, etc.), Structures (equations, algebra, linear algebra, vectors, matrices, number theory, combinatorics, group theory, order theory), Spaces (Geometry, Trignonometry, Fractal Geometry, Topology, Measure theory, differential geometry), Changes (Calculus, Vector Calculus, Dynamical Systems, Fluid flow, Ecosystmes, Chaos theory, Complex Analysis)

Mathematical Physics, Mathematical Chemistry, BioMathematics, Engineering, Numerical Anslsys, Game theory, Economics, Probability, Control theory, Decision Theory, Information Theory, Statistics, Mathematical finance, Optimization, Computer Science, cryptography
Fundamental rules (consistent set of axioms, Godel's Incompleteness Theorem, Mathematical Logic, Set Theory, Graph Theory, Category Theory, Theory of Computation, Complexity

Counting (other animals can count as well, evidence of human counting goes back to prehistoric times, checkmarks in bones, 50,000BCE), first equation (Egypt, 3000 BCE), strides in geometry, numerology (Greeks, 600-300BCE), Negative numbers (China 200 BCE), Zero as a number first used (India c628), Algebra (Persia c.820), Mathematical notation (Renaissance c.1730)

Natural numbers (counting, cardinality, order), Integers (contain negative numbers), Rational numbers (fractions, decimals, continuous), Real numbers (pi, infinite deciaml points, radicals, e), Complex Numbers (Imaginary), quaternion, octonion, cardinal numbers, prime (nubmers with interesting properties), exponential, infinity (Properties of numbering systems, not just a number, some infinities are bigger than others.
